results.title: Sacred groves [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Caryl Ebenezer, J Williams, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, Opus Television, S4C International and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Celts”.
The third in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000, this time with a focus on the Celts of Great Britain, Ireland and Wales and the ancient pagan religion of Druidism and its translation into the present day. The program discusses the fertility rights, rituals and burial rights that formed a large part of Celtic folk tradition and their mythology about the world after death with a focus on archaeological findings of riches and human remains in burial mounds as well as in peat bogs throughout Wales. The foundation of our present day Halloween in the ancient Celtic Feast of the Dead, where the earthly and supernatural world were said to intersect with nightmarish possibilities, is given as a striking example of a softened contemporary translation of ancient folklore. To this end a study is also made of the present day translation of Celtic religion, seen as a fairly removed version of the powerful Druidism of ancient times where, firmly routed in an engagement with nature, Druids were trained for twenty years to take their position in the highest priestly caste of the three orders and where great importance was placed on poetic Bards, sacrifice and no less than 200 gods and goddesses. The Druids’ fearful appearance to the Romans is also detailed, along with the stories of Druid rebellion against Roman invasion, let down in the end by lack of organisation against the most disciplined army of the world at that time and resulting in many elements of Druidism being banned or encapsulated in Catholicism.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Caryl Ebenezer, J Williams, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, Opus Television, S4C International and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)

results.title: Heroes in defeat [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Caryl Ebenezer, J Williams, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, Opus Television, S4C International and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Celts”.
The second in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. A study of rock art and archaeological findings of jewellery and various artefacts opens the program with a discussion of their symbolism that has remained relatively unknown for centuries save for their significance to key events and rituals inherent in the Celtic civilisation and their stylistic originality now known as ‘Celtic Art’. The program then traces the breakdown of Celtic society in the fifth century BC as a mass movement South of the Celtic population on the continent led to clashes with Rome and Delphi and a distribution of Celtic peoples to unexpected corners of the globe with a discussion of the great many theories that seek to explain this. The Celts in Britain are then examined in detail, with explanation of the ancient history associated with their presence there and the powerful farming, artistic and warrior traditions of their society. In tandem, the growth of the threat of the new Roman Empire to the Celts and the invasion of Celt’s new developing urban centres throughout the continent is detailed where despite the emergence of revolutionary leaders the strength of the Celts was no match for the discipline and well informed warfare techniques of the Roman soldiers. As the Roman Empire expanded its outreach Celtic Britain also came under attack but with a view to the next instalment in the series, it is said that they weren’t quite as successful in this endeavour as many believe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Caryl Ebenezer, J Williams, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, Opus Television, S4C International and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)

results.title: In the beginning [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Caryl Ebenezer, J Williams, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, Opus Television, S4C International and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Celts”.
The first in a six part series that discusses the history and legends of the Celtic people of Early Europe through to the year 2000. This episode asks the questions as to what defines the Celts, both in myth and in genetics. The program opens with discussion of the origins of the Celts in central Europe, far from where they later settled, and examines their distinctive culture and rituals as evidenced in cave drawings, writings of other cultures and archaelogical findings. The tradition of sunworshipping, the movement westward as the weather changed and the gradual move to the iron age is discussed along with the changes in power structures, produce and cultural influences in the Celtic world as trade and thus riches increased. These elements are discussed with reference to archaelogical study while acknowledging the indefinate nature of the history of the Celtic people. The questions that arise as to how they got to Ireland, the area where the contemporary true Celts remain, are investigated with reference to conflicting theories about coastal migration patterns of the time or the ambiguous archaeological evidence which is featured in the area in order to illustrate some possibilities given the difficulty of tracing Celtic history. A study is also recorded in this program of the population in present day Celtic areas and their heritage through a genetic heritage testing project with local school children and a discussion of their family heritage. While the study is seen to shed an interesting light on tracing Celtic history through genetic means it also confirms and engages with the discussion in the rest of the program of the enigma that the Celts remain.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Caryl Ebenezer, J Williams, Comataldh Craolaidh Gaidhlig, Opus Television, S4C International and Sianel 4 Cymru (S4C) (Channel 4 Wales)

group_works.title: People (Yallourn's Royal Hour 1954; Born to Die; Sir John Monash)

video_links.name: People (Yallourn's Royal Hour 1954; Born to Die; Sir John Monash)

results.title: People (Yallourn's Royal Hour 1954; Born to Die; Sir John Monash)

video_links.name: People (Yallourn's Royal Hour 1954; Born to Die; Sir John Monash)

results.brief_description: “Yallourn’s Royal Hour” highlights the visit to Yallourn of Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh on 3rd March 1954. Film of the royal motorcade through Melbourne is shown before their arrival in Yallourn where they inspect the coal extraction site at Yallourn Cut (16 min). “Born to Die” focuses on the prospect that Yallourn will be demolished to enable access to the coal reserves beneath it. Includes comments by the townspeople on their feelings about this. (48 mins) “Sir John Monash” is a tribute to the life of this pioneer Australian. The Vice Chancellor of Monash University speaks on his life and an account of his achievements is given. (27 min)
results.title_for_label: People (Yallourn’s Royal Hour 1954; Born to Die; Sir John Monash)

results.title: High voltage
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson, Australian National Film Board and SEC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “SEC Documentary films from the period 1950-1993”.
Building Victoria’s 500KV system: recounts the building of Victoria’s 500KV line for power transfer from the Yallourn Power Station to Melbourne. Shows planning and testing of towers, film of actual construction of line land clearing and excavation of sites for towers. The film describes some of the planning and construction of the 500KV line - designed to carry power from the future generating stations of the Latrobe Valley to the local centre in Melbourne. Shows rolling out and cutting of the power cabling, installation of equipment at Hazelwood Plant, preparation and countdown for energizing in June, 1970. Photography by Jim Hayes. “Along the power lines” (1962): dramatised account of the work of the mobile repair units of the SEC. Shows film of the irrigation reservoir at Eildon and pipelines at Kiewa, power lines crossing the Murray River Valley joining New South Wales with Victoria and the various parts involved in the process of electricity production from brown coal. Footage of the power plants and lines shows inside the control centre near Melbourne, with the technicians at work monitoring the load on supply. Photography by John Leake with aerial photography by Jim Hayes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shan Benson, Australian National Film Board and SEC

results.title: Coal Power
results.brief_description: Includes “Power from the Valley”, outlining the process of brown coal mining in the La Trobe Valley and its eventual consumption in a turbine generator. (12 min) “Demolition of Yallourn Briquette Chimney” looks at the demolition of the historic briquette production plant at yallourn. Directed by Jim Hayes. (4 min) “The Timeless Force” is a history of the harnessing of energy and its eventual application by the SEC. Gives a history of the SEC’s early years. This film narrated by John Stanton. (29 min)

(4 min) “The Timeless Force” is a history of the harnessing of energy and its eventual application by the SEC. Gives a history of the SEC’s early years. This film narrated by John Stanton. (29 min)

results.title: Celebrations
results.brief_description: Features two films recounting the history and development of the SEC. “Fifty Years of Service” focuses on the history of electricity in Victoria from the late 1800’s to the development of the SEC in 1919. Highlights the achievements of Sir John Monash, the first General Manager and Chairman of the SEC. Looks at the development of power plants at Yallourn, Morwell, Hazelwood and Kiewa. Examples of the impact of electricity on domestic life at the time is shown with new appliances such as hair dryers and vacuum cleaners entering the home. (33 min) “Generations of Power” is another historical retrospective this time with comments from several SEC staff members from between the 1940’s to 1990’s. Includes a decade by decade look at the impact of electricity on Victorian Society. (23 min)

results.title: 1960's productions
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and SECV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “SEC Documentary films from the period 1950-1993”.
This tape is a compilation of 4 programs: “The Briquette story”: Explains the formation of brown coal and its processing into briquettes at the Yallourn open cut. Using the vehicle of a young couple selecting appropriate heating for their new home. The program outlines the convenience and versatility of briquettes for heating, cooking and hot water generation. The value of briquettes in commercial and industrial usage is also explained. “Valley of power” (prod. writer, Shan Benson): Looks at the importance of the Latrobe Valley, site of the world’s largest single brown coal field, to Victoria. Outlines the economic and lifestyle benefits that the power industry and its supporting infrastructure has brought to the towns of Yallourn, Traralgon, Moe and Morwell. Includes commentary from local identities Willis Connolly, Les Haine, Campbell Husten and Mrs Thompson. “Power makers” (dir. Lee Robinson): Looks at a typical day in the life of four “power makers” - workers at the Yallourn power station. We are shown the important work performed by dredger crews, train drivers, boiler hands, turbine attendants and other tradesmen. Features workers George Fisher, Jack Morris, Rowley Paul and Frank Robertson. “Behind the switch”: Every switch is a demand for instant electricity. The Latrobe Valley brown coal provides four-fifths of electricity. Shows work at Yallourn and Morwell and progress on the new Hazelwood power station. Use of electricity in industry, at home, for transport, and entertainment. Increasing demands are a measure of the State’s growth and rate of development. Emphasis on ability to meet future demands.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shan Benson, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and SECV

results.title: 1950's productions
results.creator_credit: Frank Hurley and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “SEC Documentary films from the period 1950-1993”.
This tape is a compilation of 4 programs: “Brown coals to briquettes”: Classroom film showing the manufacture of briquettes at Yallourn and Morwell, Victoria. Includes demonstration by models of processes; operation of coal dredges at open cut; crushing and drying of coal; pressing of fine powder into briquettes; transport of finished product to other parts of Victoria. “Brown coal to kilowatts”: Classroom film describing the processes by which wet, raw brown coal from the Yallourn open cut is burned in specially designed boilers to produce steam for use in turbines for the generation of electric power. Laboratory demonstration, models, and diagrams explain the principles of operation of plant seen in use at Yallourn. “Romance of brown coal”: Illustrates how brown coal has been formed in the Latrobe Valley. Also shows the mining of brown coal and the conveyance of the coal from the open cut to the power house and briquetting plant. “Pageant of power”: Looks at open-cut mining and processing of brown coal at Yallourn, both for power generation and briquette production. Creation of Yallourn as an exemplary company town, plus references to early hydro-electric power stations located in north eastern Victoria.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank Hurley and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
